Problem:
Consider a complex function defined by \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a constant frequency. The function represents a signal in the complex plane, oscillating with time. We study the effect of applying a Fourier transform to this function to analyze its spectral properties.

If a phase shift transformation, defined by \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t + \phi} \\) where \\( \phi \\) is a constant phase, is applied before computing the Fourier transform, will the spectrum still show a single frequency at \\( \omega \\) without shifts?
Explanation: The phase shift \\( \phi \\) in the time domain translates into a modified phase in the frequency domain without altering the location of the frequency component. Thus, the spectrum will still show a peak at \\( \omega \\), confirming the frequency component remains unchanged, only the phase is affected.
